handle at Advocate Mac and I also have a a podcast like everyone else my mum says

so just a little bit of an outline today we're kind of going to be breaking it up in a few different parts uh and we're

specifically and how they leak through our source code and then I'm going to do
some discovery of how we can find them in our compiled applications how we can decompile our mobile applications and
Pull Apart credentials that we find in there I'll do a bunch of demos of of all these stages so it'll be more than just
a PowerPoint presentation hopefully uh but just to get everyone on the same page are we using the terminology
Secrets a lot and just in case you're not familiar with this term basically
this is a way of saying digital authentication credentials it's typically things like your API Keys your
security certificates your encryption Keys anything that authenticates you to a service or allows
you to decrypt or ingest data the key difference with secrets and what we
might call passwords although you can have credential peers and these are definitely Secrets as well but one of
the key differences that secrets are made to be used programmatically and it's machine to machine encryption an
API key is kind of used by different Services a human isn't typing it in so
that's the kind of key difference so what we're going to be discovering is these secrets these machine to machine
identifications so how do we actually use these secrets
so modern applications have really fundamentally changed a few decades ago we built monoliths these massive uh
systems these massive applications that needed everything to run now thanks to the Reliance on the internet all these
third-party services and a change in architecture we don't need to do that if we're building an application a mobile
application we can really focus on whatever it is that our applications
doing that's different to what our competitors are doing but there's a lot of stuff that our applications just need to do by default
and we can offshore a lot of that so for example if we've got credit card processing maybe we'll use stripe
um if we're using authentication maybe we'll use OCTA if we you have some search functionality maybe you'll use
angolia if you don't want to manage your own database maybe you'll get someone like mongodb to manage it for you and
this helps us speed up our process right it makes our applications more secure in a way and it also makes it a little bit
more robust and scalable the problem is that all of these Services need to
communicate with our application so we do this through secrets so we have to indicate ourselves through Secrets
every single one of these logos or icons on here is a potential access point for an attacker as an attacker one of the
things that I'm absolutely always going to be trying to find is the secrets so that I can move into different areas of
your infrastructure but once we've built our application we need to host it somewhere so we have
secrets that deal with our infrastructure as well maybe that's on AWS we have to manage our code so we use
GitHub or something else some other kind of git or Version Control System maybe we're using data dog to analyze our data
coming through so again we have lots more secrets that need to interact with our applications in in some way and all
of these are again another attack point for for attackers another entry point for attackers we also once we've got our
application up and running we've shipped it off we need to monitor it right we want to have Integrations with slack or
zendesk or graphene to see dashboards we want to see what's happening the marketing team wants to know what's
happening so that they can focus their attentions and again more secrets and then we haven't even touched on all the
micro services that we've created ourselves so very quickly you can see that an application a mobile application
becomes a huge collection of all these different Services all of them are leveraging secrets to communicate with
themselves now as an attacker one of the things that you first want to do is persist access if I can gain entrance
entry into somewhere I want to try and get entry into as many places as I can so you can't kick me out so these
secrets are really the crown jewels of our organizations and we need to protect
them at all cost and as I'll show that's not happening very well
um so where should these secrets be stored so if we're talking specifically about mobile applications you can break
it up into a few parts you kind of have your front facing application so this is what you have on your phone it's
compiled into an APK or an IPA depending on if you're using Android and there should be no secrets in here I should
not be able to access any secrets that are stored on this mobile application the only secrets that this should
interact with directly are the ones that it creates itself so if you want to encrypt data you want to create an encryption key to encrypt that data the
application can do that but it needs to create it any third-party Secrets should never appear in your application they
should be stored in the back end in local memory like environment variables and that back end should interact with
your application so either it accesses the data from the third party Services directly and sends it to your mobile
application or it can send an encrypted secret for your mobile application to use this is a simplified version but
basically this is how we should be handling our secrets the key point is that they should never be in the mobile
application but often they quite often are and this is a lot to do of what I can
imagine is that applications on your mobile can be quite powerful they don't really need a back end to run but if you
put secrets in there and you're not handling them correctly then they're going to be very easily easy to exploit
so the first part as I'm going to look at Secrets inside source code and this is really how this topic came about is I
was doing research into Secrets generally inside source code and when they found and what I found was quite
disturbing because I realized that there was a lot that actually involved mobile applications specifically
so every year git guardian we release a report called the state of Secrets Rule and this is essentially where we scan
lots of places on the internet and we try and find how many of these secrets are out there in public spaces
one of the main places that we scan is this website here called GitHub uh you're probably familiar with it about a

using GitHub for its source control or anything else
the developers your employees are probably using it themselves it's because it's used as almost like a

accessible publicly there was over a billion commits that were made publicly last year by around about 90 and there's
94 million developers according to GitHub uh on there and there was 85 million news open source repositories so
the amount of data on GitHub is an actual fire hose so what we decided to
do is get Guardian as a bit of a challenge is we decided to scan all of it so all those 1 billion commits that
were made last year we scanned them for secrets and we found uh quite a lot
so in total we found 10 million of these secrets out there in public places on
GitHub I'll show you exactly how we did that and and and what actually happens when you leak a secret on here but this
is huge it's about 67 increase from the previous years so we know that there's
huge amounts of secrets that are happening on there uh now a lot of people will probably challenge this and

looks like a secret so we have individual detectors that actually find them so we're looking for specific
secrets we have 350 Detectives and what we actually do is we validate them as well so for example if I find an
AWS key we will check that it's valid at abrf Key so
it's pretty crazy the amount of sensitive information in here and I was kind of sifting through this uh when I
decided to dive deeper into a little bit of mobile applications but first just have a quick look at what types of

these are probably very sensitive give me access to databases we around about

common file extensions we find so for Android specific

so a better way to do it and now don't actually do it but if hypothetically you

when you make something public it's not just public we understand that if it's public if you have the the information

uh I'll just show you it here this is it this is it here you don't need authentication for this you can call

so if I just I do a quick search to try and find someone's email here you go this is this is in the metadata this is

two interesting ones that attackers will look for are the public event this is when a private repository is turned
public this is by far the most interesting because if you're building on a project and you want to make it
public when you make it public you make the entire history of that project public as well which means if someone
committed a secret on a Dev Branch a year ago it's still there and then the other one is the push event
so just to give you an idea of what actually happens here what actually
